prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Sgr A* Band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of Sgr A* in band 6 continuum. The goal is to obtain the flux density of Sgr A*. The observation should be scheduled within less than a few hours with band 9 and 10 observations.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: Bands 6, 9, and 10 should be scheduled simultaneously (separation less than a few hours) for each visit.
Bands 6, 9, and 10 should be scheduled simultaneously (separation less than a few hours) for each visit.
Bands 6, 9, and 10 should be scheduled simultaneously (separation less than a few hours) for each visit.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: These are continuum observations. We only require sufficient channel resolution to permit multi-frequency synthesis imaging and flagging of any correlator birdies. The 64 channels per window will achieve this goal.

Sgr A* is located inside of Sgr A West, which has significant structure on scales larger than 1 arcsecond. Sgr A* itself has structure on the scale of less than 100 microarcseconds at these frequencies. Our goal is to measure the flux density of this point source. Experience shows that at baselines longer than 50 klambda are sufficient to remove the effects of Sgr A West and isolate Sgr A*. Any configuration that provides resolution better than 1.5 arcsecond is sufficient provided that weather is suitable.

The accuracy of the spectrum that we obtain is dominated by absolute flux calibration. We request an rms flux density of 1 mJy, such that the thermal contribution to the accuracy is only limited by absolute calibration. Sgr A* has had a measured flux density bands 6 and 7 of 2 to 5 Jy (Bower et al 2015). Higher frequency bands may have lower flux densities depending on the steepness of the spectrum but we expect that the flux density will still exceed 1 Jy.

Sgr A* is variable with a characteristic time scale of 8^+4_-3 hours at 230 and 345 GHz (Dexter et al 2014). In order to generate an accurate instantaneous spectrum, science goals for bands 6, 9, and 10 must be carried out sequentially over a period of time less than a few hours. In order to sample different states of variability, we request that epochs be separated by at least one day.

Sgr A* is located inside of Sgr A West, which has significant structure on scales larger than 1 arcsecond. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The millimeter/submillimeter spectrum of the Galactic Center supermassive black hole, Sagittarius A*, originates from within a few Schwarzschild radii of the event horizon. Determination of the turnover frequency and spectral index after the turnover is critical for assessing the optical depth of the emission and the maximum electron temperature present in the accretion flow and/or jet. These measurements will set important boundary conditions for models of the Event Horizon Telescope images of Sgr A*, directly enabling constraints on the nature of accretion and outflow,black hole spin, and tests of general relativity. Specifically, we propose to obtain spectra at frequencies from 230 to 900 GHz (bands 6, 9, and 10) of Sgr A*. There are only limited prior observations for Sgr A* up to 690 GHz and no interferometric observations at 900 GHz. Our ALMA Cycle 2 observations show that the spectrum of Sgr A* is flat between 230 and 345 GHz (bands 6 and 7). The spectrum must turn over steeply at THz frequencies in order to connect with near infrared spectra. Since Sgr A* is variable in total flux density and spectral index at all wavelengths, we request three epochs.
